Notes: A bisyllabic root. In Konda it is found only with derivative suffixes, but Kui has preserved the simple form.
Hardly a proper PGn root (all the forms could have easily been borrowed from Telugu).
The Kui-Kuwi forms are probably borrowed from Telugu, because geminated-ḍḍ-is not usually reconstructed for PGn.

Additional forms: Also Kondaaḍamacross;aḍe biḍeall over (lit. crosswise); disorganizedly
Also KondaaḍgiR/i/that which is underneath;aḍgiRaṇḍfrom below, from the bottom

Notes: The Konda form unexpectedly changed conjugation type (aṭ-can only go back to*aḍ-C-). Vowel length in PK is irregular; as a matter of fact, Kuwi_Su has shorta-, so this variant is probably more archaic.

The root was probably not used by itself in PGn. The form in Konda goes back to an old causative (hence the devoicing:aṭ-<*aḍ-p-), and there are derivatives with the suffix-mb-(in PK) and with the suffixes-ŋ-and-s-(in Konda).

The root was heavily used with posessive prefixes. The most frequent form is*yay-'my mother'. In some dialects this form became generalized, with the following shift of meaning: 'my mother' > 'mother in general', 'mother' > 'woman'. A new form, based on the 1st person pl. pronoun (Gondimāy-, Kuwimāya) resulted from the loss of initialy-and the secondary merger of the simple and the prefixed forms.

Additional forms: Also Kondaaymawoman, wife;aylidaughter, girl;yāyamother (related to 1st or 2nd person);aysiid. (related to 3rd person)

Notes: This deictic base had the following declineable forms in PGn:*aw-ant_[-u](whence Gondi*ōn-R, Kondavānr_uwith a metathese, etc.) 'that man', plural*aw-ar[-u]'those men'; fem.*a-d-i(PK*ādiby analogy with masculine forms), plural*a-v-i. Also reconstructed for the PGn level is*a-c-'that many, that much' (PG, PPM, PK);*a-tal'that side' (Konda, PK, possibly Gondi);*a-mb-/*a-b-'there' (Konda, PPM, PK).  An enormous number of derivatives has been formed independently in different languages (which is characteristic of all deictic bases).

Additional forms: Also Kondavār/u/(obl.vari-),adi(obl.dani-),avi(obl.vanka-) those men, that woman or thing, those women or things;akan,akar,akad,akeŋid.;atal(obl.ataR-) that side;ataR/i/of that side;ataRaṇḍfrom that side;abe/bān(obl.abeṇ-/bāṇ-) there;abeṇi/bāṇiof that place, belonging to that place;abekanman belonging there;āR/u/in that way, so, thus;ayaadj. that;ayakanthat man, etc.; (Sova dialect)anigathere;akodistant; distance; (Sova dialect)akoṇḍdistant;nanithat sort of;nanikansuch a man, etc.;nanuone (woman or thing) like that;nasothat much, that big;nasoṇḍarthat many men;nasoṛ/nasoṇḍthat many women or things;nasokid., such big ones

Notes: Although the resonant here is most certainly a plain dental-l-, it becomes retroflex in Konda (cf. especially such derivative forms asaṛpa-). This is not quite clear; maybe it is a general feature of *-l- before the causative marker. Unfortunately, this is the only example of such a cluster (in a few other cases we have no BB forms with-ṛ-, which are diagnostic).

Additional forms: Also Kondaalpa- (-t-) to twist or twine, plait or weave a cot, weave a garland;aṛpa-(-t-) to spread as a creeper;alṭay ā-to be interwoven, grow thickly and densely as a creeper

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to level, spread out (as pieces of wood after the forest is felled, in order to let them dry)
to join two pieces together, fit one into or on another
term of endearment used in addressing a familiar person

Notes: The Gondi semantic shift to 'father' can be connected with the "extra" suffix-l.

Meaning: grandmother; used in addressing wife in a folktale

Notes: The Proto-Gondwan character of this root is dubious, especially since the regular reflex of PDR*-mb-in Gondi is-m-. Some, or all of the forms, could have been re-borrowed from Telugu.

Additional forms: Also Kondaanasielder brother (with reference to 3rd person)

Notes: In Kui a shift of meaning: 'father' > 'son' (such a shift happens in SDR as well, when the word for 'father' is applied to children as term of endearment).
Possibly more than one root involved; unfortunately, Gondwan reflexes of former bisyllabic verbal bases with a vocalic anlaut are quite poorly studied.

Meaning: to plaster (walls), anoint (body or body parts), clean (teeth, etc.)
Additional forms: Also Kondarāsay ā-to apply oil, turmeric, etc., to one's own body;rāspis-to cause to apply oil, plaster

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondaarap-to fell, make to fall

Notes: The root was used only with the suffix*-k-(assimilated to the voiced*-r_-after reduction in Konda and PK).

Meaning: (food) to be digested, be worn out

Notes: Causative type of conjugation in PGn.

Meaning: to stick to, remain stable (in a village); to catch, hold, grasp
to attach, join (any broken part); to be joined, attached
to burn (heaps of hacked forest-wood, before starting pōṛu cultivation), set fire to

Notes: A questionable etymology with unique correspondences between Konda and PPM; the exact match in semantics, however, suggests that Burrow & Emeneau's comparison is valid. See also external parallels.

Meaning: to choose, select, clean impurities from rice, sift

Notes on correspondences: PGn*-ṛ> Konda-l(-ṛin some dialects). In some Kui-Kuwi dialects the plural form has been generalised.

Additional forms: Also Kondaālsiid. (related to 3rd person);āl māsirwife and husband;āṛuwife (N. and W. dialects)

Notes: Bisyllabic root. In Konda and PPM it was used with a suffix: *āñd_ur-ka > *ānd_r-ka > *ānd_-ga, *ānd_-i-ka. In PK reduction of the second syllable led to a general simplification of the cluster.
The verb was used with the suffix-p-in PGn.
Causative conjugation only.
The actual PGn form is*badk-, since the root was regularly used with the plural action suffix.
Initial *p- in PKK absolutely irregular. ??
PK vocalism is not quite clear. Considering that the whole form is*buṭ-u, we may suggest assimilation, probably assisted by the initial labial.

Meaning: drop of water, mark on forehead

Notes: In PK contamination with*pot-'sapling, twig' ( < 'young').

Meaning: small vessel made of scooped gourd shell
Additional forms: Also Kondapur_gedrinking vessel made of gourd shell;bur_ahead

Notes: The exact nature of the inlaut cluster (phoneme?) is hard to determine: PK and PPM show*-r-, Konda speaks in favor of*-ṛ-, while Gondi gives several variants (*-y-,*-r-,*-l-; one dialect even has a unique*-ḷ-).

Meaning: pubic hair, feathers, hair (on legs and chest)

Notes: Causative conjugation in PGn (which explains voiceless reflexes everywhere).

Meaning: to slap with hand, clap hands, thrash (as clothes against a rock in washing)

Notes: PPMj-is not quite clear. It can only be explained through assimilation (*sāc->*cāc-)  and then (!) dissimilation (*cāc->jāc-). The root itself had a velar suffix in its intransitive form (*sā-ŋ-) and a palatal causative suffix (*sā-c-).

Meaning: (body or limbs) to be stretched out to full length
Additional forms: Also Kondasāk-to stretch out (fingers, limbs);sāp-to stretch out (tongue, hands, legs)

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
The exact relationship of this root with PK*crī-'to rot, decay' and PGn*sī-'pus, snot' (DEDR 1606) is yet to be defined.

Meaning: to plane, fashion things out of wood
to be crushed (as an overripe fruit)

Notes: Vowel length in PK (Kui, exactly) is unclear, although in derivatives short -a- is also met.

Meaning: to hop, jump, hop in dance, jump over, walk fast

Notes: The initial cluster was probably preserved in PK (although the exact phonetic character is doubtful). However, the form was reinterpreted asdye+ʔoli, i.e. the old root auslaut was confounded with a derivative suffix. The Konda form dates back to an old plural form (sōŋa<*jol-ŋa).

Meaning: backyard of house (for plants, etc. to grow)

Notes: It seems that*ḍog-meant 'lizard', while its derivative*ḍog-ḍ-meant 'chameleon'; the latter is seen in Gondi_Trḍoggaland PK.

Meaning: to be got or acquired, be available, be caught or defeated
Additional forms: Also KondadoRkis-to make available, bring out

Notes: Kui*-ṛ-unclear.

Various assimilations, progressive as well as regressive, tend to obscure the root's consonantism. The formdupaby itself is only fixed in Konda by Burrow and Bhattacharya and in Kuwi_Isr, but it is the different types of assimilation that give away the original root structure.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to shoot (arrow), fling or pelt (with a stone)

Notes: In DED PPM and PK forms are erroneously compared with SDR*cāy-'to incline'; this is impossible because of the initial consonant.

Meaning: to go down, set (as sun), dismount, descend

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Most of the seeming irregularities in this root's reflexation are the result of its joining with the root*vā-'to come' (*ey-v-). This form is seen in Gondi*ev-(and not*ey-) and PK*ey-v-. In PPM the old suffixal form*ey-k(probably a nominal derivative) was also used only withvā-. Kondaī-is irregular as well; maybe developed from*eyv-.
PK*eŋg-is secondary (formed as an anti-causative for*ek-), since it is not supported by any external data.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondaes-(-t-) to leave or save (food, etc.) for others, let something remain, leave over

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondaeris-to cause to burn, let someone light a fire

Meaning: to carry child on waist, take child into lap

Notes: The root has an old suffixal-l-which is also seen in several other cases. It may be bisyllabic, but this is hard to prove. The causative form ('to winnow') was*ed_-l-c-> Kondaer_lis-, PK*ēRs-(original alveolar phoneme preserved because of*-l-; without it*eh-would be expected). PPM*zēc-> Pengojēc-has NOTHING! NOTHING! to do with this!!!

Meaning: to separate (as one's legs), keep away from
Additional forms: Also Kondaēr_p-(-t-) to keep apart, keep separate

Meaning: to become large, (family) to increase in size

Notes: The origins of PK-n-are not quite clear. Perhaps it results from*gaḍ-nḍiwith a metathese.
Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: basket in which to carry grain

Notes: The inlaut cluster is*-nt-("weak cluster"); vocalism correspondences are unclear. The root is uncertain, since borrowing from Telugu is not excluded.

Additional forms: Also Kondagelpis-(-t-) to save, rescue, cause to win or become eminent

Meaning: a k. of bird of prey
Notes: Since the form is only present in a single Gondi dialect, vowel length in PGn cannot be determined for certain.

Meaning: a bamboo pipe to keep a cigar in

Notes: There were actually several 'hook'-roots in PGn (see also*kōnḍ-; one should also probably reconstruct*kok-, cf. Gondikokkihoe, etc.), and naturally they all hopeleslly contaminated with each other. That is why we have Konda and PK*k-.

Meaning: a hook fixed on a wall used as a hanger

Notes: In Konda secondary devoicing by assimilation.

Meaning: to raise and project the head (while seeing a distant object)

Notes: The reasons for such obviously irregular reflexation in all dialects except PPM are a) assimilations  (*-m->-p-through assimilation with*g-) and b) contamination with*kup-'mound,  hillock'. However, such forms as Pengogomoṇclearly point to a different root. There is also a strange Kuwi_Su formgu'uwith an unclear glottal stop. Were it possible to trace it back to*gumu(?), the PK reconstruction should have been altered.
A "weak cluster" in PGn.
External data shows *g- to be primary.
The root often contaminated with*kūḍ-'a k. of cage'.

Meaning: a fowl-shelter fixed on the top of a floor in a house
to lie down, fall; to sleep
Notes: Initial*k-in Kui is hard to understand. Maybe it is influenced by Telugukuriyu'to rain, shower'; more probably, there has been contamination with*kurk-'to be drowsy, sleep', although the latter is not preserved in Kui.

Meaning: to lie down, sleep, roll on floor

Notes: The declineable forms in PGn are analogical to those formed from*a-(*iwanr_u'this man', etc.).

Additional forms: Also Kondavēr/u/(obl.veri-),idi(obl.deni-),ivi(obl.venka-) these men, this woman or thing, these women or things;ikan,ikar,ikad,ikeŋid.;ital(obl.itaR-) this side;itaR/i/of this side;itaRaṇḍfrom this side;ibe/bēn(obl.ibeṇ-/bēṇ-) here;ibeṇi/bēṇiof this place, belonging to this place;ibekanman belonging here;īR/u/in this manner, like this;iya(variantyā) adj. this;iyakanthis man, etc.;iyel,ēlnow;iyoṇḍthis year;ninithis type or manner;ninikanthis sort of man, etc.;ninuones (women or things) like this;nisothis many, this much;nisoṇḍar,nisok/nisoṛ/nisoṇḍthese many men, these many women or things

Notes: Inlaut consonant is unclear. In PPM we have causative conjugation, so*iṭ-can possibly <*iḍ-; however, in PK simple forms are present (Kuiiṭa, etc.).

Additional forms: Also Kondaiṭki-(-t-) to put on (ornament), insert (flowers behind ear), wear a beauty mark

Notes: The Konda form goes back to an old suffixal*iṛ-Vy-. The root is not bisyllabic, as shown by PPM.

Additional forms: Also Kondair_aŋatightly (of clothing);ir_zutightness (of shirt, bracelet, etc.);ir_mubeing too narrow (of house)

Meaning: to serve (food), put, pour in or out
(part of the body) to be sprained

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: (water) to be evaporated, dry up (in summer), (floods) to subside in a river

Notes: See also PG*ir-vurtwo (masc.) Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondarunḍitwo (fem. and neut.);riʔertwo men;riʔeṭwe two;riʔideryou two;rineṇḍtwo days;riyaŋatwo sides;rizatwice;ruṭkulakaat the rate of two, two each

Notes: Bisyllabic root; in Konda there has been a metathese (*usik->*isuk-) or an assimilation (*usik->*isik-).
Irregular PK*d-(although Winfield has bothd-andḍ-in Kui). Gondi and Konda show an old suffix*-k-.

Meaning: to descend, dismount; drip down (as oil from oil-press, flour from grinding-stone, etc.)
Additional forms: Also Kondaḍip-to cause to descend or come down, put or take down; to leave

Notes: Bisyllabic root and causative conjugation in PGn. The reflexation*ḍr-in PK is strange. Maybe it is possible to connect it with vowel length? (like, for example,*iṛi->*iṛi->*ṛi-, but*īṛi->*ʔṛi->*ḍri-).

Additional forms: Also Kondaīṛispis-to make to drag;īṛay ā-to drag oneself along the ground

Notes: Bisyllabic root, as seen on the basis of Kui-Kuwi and Pengo-Manda data.
The word had a PK derivative:*yēt_-ki'thirst' > PG*etk-(with secondary shortening), KondaēRki, PPM*ēski, PK*ēski.
Vowel lengthening in PPM unclear.

Meaning: to meet, come together, be mixed (BB)
trench made as a fireplace during weddings

Notes: The word may be an old borrowing from IA (Skt.khaṇḍa-, whence aspiration in Gondi); then again, it may be a re-borrowing in Gondi.
Causative conjugation in Konda.

Meaning: to bring forth young (of human beings), bear children

Notes: The root is hardly bisyllabic, since there is no reduction in PK even with the derivative-ŋg-.

Meaning: fencing with dried stalks, thorny bushes, etc.
Additional forms: Also Kondakar_u(pl.kaRku) a small piece of wood, dried plants, twigs, etc.; used as fuel

Meaning: to cut down (tree) with an axe, fell
Additional forms: Also Kondakatki-(-t-) to cut down (trees);kataslopping, cutting;katas ā-to cut one another

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
-l-is an old suffix here.

Meaning: neck, hollow in the nape of the neck
to wait for; to watch out for
Notes: Gondi*-ē-is unclear. Maybe the root was reinterpreted as having a*-y-auslaut, in which case*kāy-p->*kē-p-.

Additional forms: Also Kondakāp ki-to wait for, look for, waylay
Also Kondakāmb-(-it-) to be boiled (as water), get warm;kāy-(-t-) to warm oneself at fireplace; (Sova dial.)kāŋkaanger

Meaning: to carry on the shoulders; carrying yoke

Notes: The word had a causative conjugation in PGn (probably with the suffix*-p-).Hence the loss of  voice in Gondi, Konda and PPM (all these forms go back to*ked_-p->*ket_-; in PPM probably  a 'metathese of voice':*ked_->*get_-). The form*ket_-pi'door' goes back to PGn.

Meaning: to close, shut (as a door, box, etc.), build a wall (as enclosure)

Notes: Bisyllabic root with first long vowel.

Kondarēs-goes back to an old causative form, which explains-s-<*-nj-C-and aphaeresis ofk-, which is an extremely rare matter; here it is due to a "reluctant" metathese in a cluster of more than two consonants.

Meaning: to pinch, nip, squeeze with fingers

Notes: The PK form should probably be reconstructed as*gḍoveli. The form itself is compound, formed from*koḍ-'to bend' and*veli<*vali'stone'.

Meaning: to crush with the teeth, bite

Notes: Inlaut-ɣ-assimilated in most dialects; however, it is usually preserved in the absolute auslaut (like Pengokoy) and seen in Kuikog-.

Additional forms: Also Kondakogriyounger, small;kogimother's sister, father's younger brother's wife

Meaning: to reap, harvest, cut, pluck (flowers, etc.)

Notes: Maybe the root should be joined with*kos-(*kosoy?)

Meaning: pointed end (as of a leaf, etc.)

Notes: This root should not be confounded with*gond-'to cut, hack', as it is in DEDR 2091. Causative conjugation in PGn.

Meaning: to hammer, hit hard on the top

Notes: Voicening in Konda is easily explainable; however, the inlaut cluster is strange. In PPM there seems to have been desaffricativisation; as for PK, we cannot say for certain whether*-ṭigoes back to*-ri.
The second component, seen in PPM and PK, is unclear: the usual suffix is simple *-ɣ-. Cf. such forms as Tamilkuṛ-āy. Konda-u-unclear; maybe due to back articulation of preceding/following velars.

Meaning: to be hollowed out, (floor) to form pits
Additional forms: Also Kondakuṛk-(-t-) to hollow out, make pits

Notes: Such forms as Kuikrōgaor Pengokṛō-could be regarded as pointing to an old bisyllabic root. However, I think that in this case metathese should be attributed to the tendency of cluster elimination, i.e. the structure*koṛv-has a tendency >*kṛo/v/-.
The root could be a borrowing from Telugu.

Meaning: anything demanded gratis after purchasing vegetables, etc.

Notes: This root, which encapsulates the self-naming of many Dravidian tribes, is extremely hard to  reconstruct. Besides the differences in vocalism, the inlaut consonant is very hard to determine;  especially since some of the etyma may be borrowed (thus,kūbiis not the self-naming of Konda  speakers themselves, but of Konda Dora dialect speakers). The root itself seems to be an old derivative of the word for 'mountain', in Tamilkō: this form points rather to a PGn variant*kov-.

Meaning: the Konḍa Dora (the speakers of this language)

Notes: Bisyllabic root?
"Metathese of voice" in PPM and also in KondaguRi(BB) is probably due to contamination with*guṭ-'short'.

Additional forms: Also Kondakur_ikanshort man;kor_o nakajackal (small in size, opposed toperi naka)

Notes: External (SDR) data shows the original root to be*kut-. The formkund-, met in Pengo and  Manda, may represent another (although unparalleled) root with the meaning 'to strike with fist',  although both roots were contaminated, or else it is a secondary 'anti-causative' formation. Initialg-in Konda is unclear (contamination withguṭ-'to pound'?) Anyway, it is extremely hard  to deal with these roots, since there seems to be a very large 'family' of similar roots: namely, besides*kut-'to pierce', there is*kut-'to pound',*kuṭ-'to pierce',*gud-'to quarrel, fight',*guṭ-'fist, to pound'. Naturally, they have been so contaminated that it is almost impossible to reconstruct the original picture.

Meaning: to stitch (as a leaf-plate, leaf-cup, etc., flowers into a garland), pierce, butt

Additional forms: Also Konda caus.kūpis-to summon, make (somebody) call, send word

Meaning: to join, meet, assemble, come together
Additional forms: Also Kondakūṛp-to mix (cereals, etc.), join or put together, collect;kūṛaŋatogether

Notes: Bisyllabic root with reduction in Konda and PK (in Gondi >*kaṭl->*kāṛ-).
Bisyllabic root; first consonant unclear (PPM points to*k-, Konda and PK point to*g-, but the latter may as well be secondary). Note: in PPM*kṇ-probably >*kṇ-, but*gṇ->gṛ-.

Meaning: to go beyond the boundary of a village, fail a promise, disregard (elder's words)

Notes: Causative conjugation in PPM and Konda.

Meaning: to bite, sting; (hunger, thirst) to be felt
Additional forms: Also Kondakaṭis-,kaṭpis-to cause to bite or sting

Notes: Derivative of*sēd_-'to winnow', but on a very high level.
A "weak cluster". However, at least for this root it is confirmed by most dialects within Gondwan languages as well as in other ones.

Meaning: in:sītel dubu, sīntel maranudate tree, Phoenix sylvestris

Additional forms: Also Kondasumaa cloth rolled into a pad

Notes: PK*maʔe<*mat_-he<*mad_-se.

Additional forms: Also KondamaRsathe following (referring to time), e.g.maRsa nāṇḍunext day

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
Notes on correspondences: A rare type of bisyllabic nominal root with vocalic auslaut.

Additional forms: Also Kondamar_isison (referring to 3rd person); (Sova dial.)mēmar koṛoboychild

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
The form is reconstructed with *-d_k-, because *-t_k- > PK *-sk-.
PK vocalism unclear.

Meaning: to turn over (as a stone), turn upside down

Additional forms: Also Kondamoga koṛoboy child; husband, young man

Meaning: to crush under foot, tread on, walk, thresh (grain, as by oxen)

Notes: Affricate suffix in PG, cf. Tulumalejji.
Unexplainedv-in Gondi; contamination with other roots is not excluded (see DED 5265).
All the forms go back to*mari-s-(causative suffix). Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondamars-(-t-) to teach, train (as bullocks yoked to the plough)

Notes: Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to burn, (water) to boil, (body) to burn with heat

Notes: Kui-y-not quite clear; maybe it is a back-formation from*māŋga?

Additional forms: Also Kondaāl māsirhusband and wife; (Sova dial.)mēmar koṛoboy-child

Notes: PK*māsk-is a plural action form <*mād_-k-. It is a PK innovation.

Additional forms: Also Kondamāyavanishing or disappearing suddenly;māya ā-to disappear, vanish

Notes: If PK-r-is suffixal and*mṛ-<*ml-with assimilation, the comparison is justified. Bisyllabic root.

Meaning: to rub and clean utensils with ashes, etc.

Additional forms: Also Kondamī-(-t-), (Sova dial.)mēp-(-t-) to tend or graze cattle;mēpugrazing of cattle

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
Causative conjugation in PGn (with*-s-).
Strange vocalism in Konda and PPM (a unique case).
In PPM probably shortening by analogy with plural*min-k-<*mīn-k-.
In Konda contamination withnipi.
Bisyllabic root.

Additional forms: Also Kondamuṛk-(-t-) to dip in (vessel), drown (a person in a river)

Notes: Used mostly with suffixes:*mud_-s-> PG*muhc-,*mud_-l-> Kondamur_li-,*mud_-k-> PPM*murg-, PK*musk-.
Causative form in PPM. Kuimogo, Gondimoy'bud' may be borrowed from Telugu.

Meaning: to bury (as a corpse), cover (a pit), close (with lid)
erected poles in the construction of cowpen

Notes: Bisyllabic root. In Gondi a progressive assimilation. In Kui*mrāl-would be expected. It is, however, not excluded that*-r-> PK*-ṛ-before*-l-(for example, because of dissimilation of two different dental resonants; the process is thus the opposite of the one in Gondi). In PPM only Pengo data is present, so the exact vocalism is unclear; however, since PG *koṛ-aɣ- > PPM*kṛɔy-, it is very much probable that the case here is similar.

Additional forms: Also Kondamosopcloud(s), being overcast (of the sky)

Notes: Vocalism in Konda and PK is strange; probably a dissimilation in position between two labials.

Additional forms: Also Kondamūnr_ithree (neut.);mūRku mūRkuthree each;mūRku leka/lakaat the rate of three apiece;muʔ-allomorph ofmūnr_ibefore personal suffixes, e.g.muʔeṭ(1pl. incl.),muʔep(1pl. excl.) we three

Notes: Note that Kondamūnzi'nose' clearly belongs here and is related tomūnz-'to sniff' (4886), not tomūtu'beak' (5031), as Burrow and Emeneau put it.

Meaning: a small bell or tinkling ornament tied to the legs

Additional forms: Also Kondanalp-to squeeze, crush;nalŋis-to cause to squeeze

Notes: Bisyllabic root.
Konda nāṇ-ḍiŋ < *nāḷ-d-.

Additional forms: Also KondanāṇḍiRiof that day;nāṇḍiRaṇḍfrom that day onwards

Notes: Kondanāsumay not belong here; however, considering also such forms as Kuinōsuid., it may go back to*nōṇ-cuwith a suffix.

Additional forms: Also Kondanegikana good man;negeṇḍadv. good, well;negreṇḍaadv. well, fine (of living, flourishing)

Notes: PG form probably <*ney-s-.

Meaning: to weave or thatch the roof with leaves

Notes: The Gondi form may have been contaminated with another root (cf. Tamilvēliid.).

Meaning: (a plant) to rise from the seed
to sigh, respire when exhausted or tired, have hiccups while weeping

Notes: A very complicated root. PK form can go back to*nr_eʔ-<*ner_e-; PG form goes back to*nir_-n-. However, the status of Konda and Manda forms is unclear. Maybei-is a prefix (deictic base 'this'?), since loss of initialn-is impossible for both languages. In this case Kondainen<i-ner_(assimilation?), and Mandaineliŋ<*i-ner_-ŋ.

Notes: In Gondi-m-by analogy with the plural forms.

The original form was preserved in PK. In other groups*noḷ-was used only with suffixes, so  PPM*noḷ-nj->*nḷo-nj->*ṛonj-; PG*noḷ-nj-k->*nḷo-s-k->*ḷosk-.  In Konda the formlo-(causative type, from*noḷp-) probably developed by analogy withlonz-<*noḷ-nj-. There is no need to suggest that the root was originally bisyllabic, especially since it is clearly monosyllabic in PK.
